Current progresses about probable error and statistical declaration for radiative two phase flow using AgeH2O and CueH2O nanomaterials
Tasawar Hayat a,b, Sumaira Qayyum a, Muhammad Ijaz Khan a,*, Ahmed Alsaedi b
a Department of Mathematics, Quaid-I-Azam University 45320, Islamabad 44000, Pakistan b Nonlinear Analysis and Applied Mathematics (NAAM) Research Group, Department of Mathematics, Faculty of Science, King Abdulaziz University, Jeddah 21589, Saudi Arabia

Keywords: Statistical declaration AgeH2O and CueH2O nanoparticles Probable error Joule heating Thermal radiation
Two stretchable rotating disks
* Corresponding author. E-mail address: ijazfmg_khan@yahoo.com
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijhydene.2017.09.124 0360-3199/© 2017 Hydrogen Energy Publicati
Please cite this article in press as: Hayat T, phase flow using AgeH2O and CueH2O n j.ijhydene.2017.09.124
a b s t r a c t
Here modeling and computations are presented to introduce the novel concept of statis-
tical declaration and probable error for radiative flow between two stretchable rotating disks. Effects of Joule heating and thermal radiation are accounted. Homogenous and heterogeneous reactions are also implemented. The thermophysical characteristics of nanofluids are scrutinized using silver and copper nanoparticles. Statistical declaration and probable error for coefficient of skin friction and heat transfer rate are calculated. System of nonlinear ordinary differential equations is obtained by using appropriate variables. Convergent solutions of the involved problems are obtained and discussed. Skin friction coefficient and Nusselt number are calculated and discussed. Radial and axial velocities have opposite impact for stretching parameters of lower and upper disks. Concentration decays for both Schmidt number and homogeneous reaction variable. Coefficient of skin friction is less for larger rotational parameter at both disks. Opposite behavior
of heat transfer rate is observed at lower and upper disks for increasing Eckert number. For limiting cases comparisons with previously available results [23,52,53] in the literature are made and an excellent agreement is noticed.

Introduction
Nanometer sized materials such as nanorodes, nanoparticles and nanotubes in conventional fluids like oil, ethyl-glycol and water are known as nanofluids. The nanofluids are used in practical applications like protein engineering, drug delivery, cancer diagnosis and therapy, non-porous materials for size exclusion chromatography, photodynamic therapy, surgery,
(M.I. Khan).
ons LLC. Published by Els
et al., Current progresses anomaterials, Internatio
shedding new light on cells, neuro electronic interfaces, vivotherapy and molecular motors like kinesis etc. For stopping overeating now the scientists are working on nanofoods to feel fuller for longer period. Choi [1] coined theword nanofluid for the first time. After this various researchers worked on nanofluidswith different perspectives (see Refs. [2e7]). In high temperature equipments usage of MHD is remarkable e.g. power generators, the phenomenon of aviation used by an airplane's compass, electrostatic filters, droplet filters, pumps,
evier Ltd. All rights reserved.
about probable error and statistical declaration for radiative two nal Journal of Hydrogen Energy (2017), https://doi.org/10.1016/
the design of heat exchangers, accelerators, the cooling of reactors, etc. Nanofluid has unique characteristics with magnetic field and liquid (known as magnetic nanofluids). These fluids have many applications in tunable optical fiber filter, magneto-optical wavelength filter, nonlinear optical materials, optical switches, optical modulators, optical grating etc. Some more applications of magnetic nanofluids are for magnetic cell separation, contrast enhancement in magnetic resonance imaging, cancer therapy and drug delivery. Useful study about such fluids is cited in refs. [8e11]. Sheikholeslami and Zeeshan [12] analyzed the flow of copper water nanofluid with effect of heat source in a porous enclosure. Influence of coulomb forces on Fe3O4eH2O nanofluid is elucidated by Sheikholeslami et al. [13]. Sheikholeslami and Ganji [14] examined the flow of copper water nanofluid in presence of magnetic field and marangoni boundary layer. Sheikholeslami et al. [15] worked on copper water nanofluid in a complex shaped cavity. Natural convection of Fe3O4eH2O nanomaterial with thermal radiation is studied by Sheikholeslami et al. [16]. Hayat et al. [17] studied flow of micropolar nanofluid accounting thermophoresis and brownian motion effects. Khan et al. [18] worked on Carreau nanofluid flow in presence of MHD and solar energy aspects. Haq et al. [19] considered the vertically heated sheet to study the mixed convective flow. Ijaz et al. [20] investigated consequences of nonlinear thermal radiation in mixed convection flow of magneto-Walter-B nanomaterial.
Flow by rotating surfaces gained much attention of the researchers and scientists. It is because of its usage in engineering and industrial sectors including jet motors, food processing, electric power generating system and turbine system. Therefore theoretical and experimental studies for this type of flow seem interesting. Pioneer work on flow due to rotating disk is due to Karman [21]. He provided transformations which help us to construct ordinary differential equation from Navier Stokes equations. Cochran [22] then examined rotating disk flow by numerical integration technique. Rotating flow by two disks is firstly examined by Stewartson [23]. Chapple and Stokes [24] and Mellor et al. [25] also examined flow between rotating disks. Heat transfer in flow for two rotating disks is explored by Arora and Stokes [26]. Kumar et al. [27] described flow between porous stationary disk and solid rotating disk. Hayat et al. [28] discussed thermal stratification effects in rotating flow between two disks.
Homogeneouseheterogeneous reactions are involved in various reacting systems. Except in the presence of catalyst some of the reactions does not work or may be proceed very slow. There exists a complex correlation between homogeneouseheterogeneous reactions. Fog formation and dispersion, crops damage via freezing, food processing, ceramics and polymer production, hydrometallurgical industry are applications of chemical reaction. Hence the scientists are engaged in the discussion of flows with homogeneousheterogeneous reactions [29e34].
Phenomenon by which the passage of an electric current through a conductor releases heat is called Joule heating. Electric stove, thermistors, incandescent light bulb, food processing equipment and electric cigarette are some
Please cite this article in press as: Hayat T, et al., Current progresses phase flow using AgeH2O and CueH2O nanomaterials, Internatio j.ijhydene.2017.09.124
examples of Joule heating. Ramzan et al. [35] studied Joule heating in flow of micropolar fluid with convective boundary condition and slip effects. Jeffrey fluid flow by stretching surface with Joule heating and power law heat flux is analyzed by Babu and Narayana [36]. Viscous dissipation and Joule heating effects in flow of Cu-water nanofluid is addressed by Hayat et al. [37]. Effect of Joule heating on channel sidewalls induced sample dispersion in rectangular ducts is examined by Dutta [38]. Hayat et al. [39] worked on MHD flow of thixotropic nanofluid subject to Joule heating and convective conditions.
Silver and copper water nanofluids flow between two stretchable rotating disks with homogeneous-heterogeneous reactions is not yet studied. The objective here is to fill this void. Radiative and Joule heating effects are also addressed. Convergent series solutions are developed through HAM [40e50]. Through graphs and tables, the impacts of different parameters on velocity, temperature, concentration, skin friction coefficient and Nusselt number are shown and discussed.
Physical model and mathematical formulation
Consider nanofluid flow between two continuously stretching rotating disks. Statistical declaration and probable error for coefficient of skin friction and heat transfer rate are calculated. We have considered silver ðAgÞ and copper ðCuÞ as nanoparticles and water (H2O) as a base fluid. Lower disk at z ¼ 0 is rotating with angular velocity U1 in axial direction and stretching rate a1 while upper disk (at distance h apart) rotates with angular velocity U2 and stretching rate a2 (see Fig. 1).

Convergence analysis
In homotopy analysis series solutions, the auxiliary parameters Z~f ; Z~g; Z~q and Z~f have pivotal role in adjusting the convergence region. For suitable values of these parameters we draw the Z curves at 9th order of approximations (see Figs. 2 and 3)). Suitable ranges for Ag water nanofluid are 2:2 Z~f 0:4; 2:4 Z~g 0:1; 0:9 Z~q 0:1 and 1:2 Z~f 0:1: For Cu-waternanofluid theadmissible rangesare 2:2 Z~f 0:4; 2:4 Z~g 0:1; 0:8 Z~q 0:2 and. 1 Z~f 0:1:
Table 1 includes thermophysical properties of silver, copper and water. Also the convergence of series solutions for both silver and copper water nanofluid is displayed in Tables 2 and 3. For silver water nanofluid 7th order of approximation is appropriate for convergence of velocity in x direction ~f ''ð0Þ and temperature profile ~q'ð0Þ and 8th and 11th order of approximations are sufficient for convergence of velocity in y direction ~g''ð0Þ and concentration profile ~f'ð0Þ (see Table 2). Now for copper water nanofluid 11th iteration is sufficient for the convergence of velocity in both directions and temperature and concentration profile converge upto 10th and 15th order of approximations respectively (see Table 3). Table 4
Please cite this article in press as: Hayat T, et al., Current progresses phase flow using AgeH2O and CueH2O nanomaterials, Internatio j.ijhydene.2017.09.124
shows the comparison of present flow with previous literature and we found it in an excellent agreement.
Surface drag force
Impact of different involved parameters on surface drag force at lower and upper disks for M ¼ 0:1 and M ¼ 0:7 is examined in Tables 5 and 6. It is noted that for silver and copper water nanofluids the skin friction coefficient is an increasing function of Hartmann number M, stretching parameter A2, nanoparticle volume fraction fwhile it shows decreasing behavior for Reynolds number Re and rotation parameter t at lower disk. At upper disk the surface drag force is increasing function of M; A2; Re, f and it decreases for t. It is noted that silver and copper water nanofluids have same results quantitatively.
Nusselt number
Behaviors of embedded parameters on Nusselt number at lower and upper disks forM ¼ 0:1 andM ¼ 0:7 are examined in Tables 7 and 8. It is noted that for both silver and copper water nanofluids the Nusselt number enhances for larger nanoparticle volume fraction f, stretching parameter A1; radiation parameter R while it shows decreasing behavior for Reynolds number Re and Eckert number Ec at lower disk. Radial and axial velocity components
Impact of Reynolds number Re for radial and axial velocities is described in Figs. 4 and 5. It is shows that with an increase in Re the magnitude of velocity decreases for lower disk because inertial forces have direct relationwith Re so velocities reduce. Velocity of upper disk is more than lower one. Impact ofA1 for radial and axial velocities is shown in Figs. 6 and 7. With an increment in values of A1 the velocities in radial and axial directions enhance near the lower disk and magnitude of these velocities decays near the upper disk because A1 is increasing continuously. In axial velocity negative values near the upper disk indicate that velocity of lower disk ismore than upper disk. Figs. 8 and 9 portray the influence ofA2 on ~f 'ðxÞ and

Behavior of rotational parameter t is examined in Figs. 10 and 11. We noted that ~f 'ðxÞ and ~fðxÞ decay near the lower disk andmagnitude of these velocities increases at upper disk. It is due to the fact that for larger t rotation at upper disk enhances so velocity is more at upper disk. Impact of Hartmann number for axial velocity is displayed in Fig. 12. Hartmann number is associated with the Lorentz force which is

Temperature profile
Fig. 17 is displayed to show impact of Hartmann numberM on qðxÞ: As we increase the values of M the fluid temperature enhances. In fact M depends upon Lorentz force which is resistive force so heat produces and consequently temperature increases. Figs. 18 and 19 show that temperature has opposite impact for larger values of A1 and A2. Influence of Re on temperature is described in Fig. 20. Here ~qðxÞ is an increasing function of Re. Figs. 21 and 22 are portrayed to

show the impact of radiation parameter R and Eckert number Ec on ~qðxÞ. Radiative heat transfer rate enhances with an increase in R because for larger R the coefficient of mean absorption decreases thus fluid temperature increases (see Fig. 21). With an increase in values of Ec resistance between the particles enhances and heat produces. This leads to an increase in temperature (see Fig. 22).

For higher Sc there is reduction in mass diffusivity because Sc is the ratio of viscosity tomass diffusivity so there is reduction in the fluid concentration. Fig. 27 shows that concentration of fluid decays by increasing k1 because reactants are consumed during the homogeneous reactions. Same results are observed for Ag and Cu nanoparticles.
Final remarks
Here we studied radiative MHD nanofluid flow between two stretchable and rotating disks with homogeneous and heterogeneous reactions and Joule heating. Main points are as follows:
Radial and axial velocities enhance at lower disk for larger A1 while for A2 the velocities are increasing near the upper disk. Tangential velocity is increasing for larger stretching and rotational parameters. Fluid temperature qðxÞ enhances for larger R and Ec. Stretching parameters A1 and A2 have opposite impact for concentration profile fðxÞ. Concentration of fluid reduces for larger Sc and k1. Surface drag force is less for larger t at both disks. Influence of A1 on heat transfer rate for upper and lower disks are opposite. All results are quantitatively similar for silver and copper water nanofluids.

[39] worked on MHD flow of thixotropic nanofluid subject to Joule heating and convective conditions.

metadata.abstractText: Here modeling and computations are presented to introduce the novel concept of statistical declaration and probable error for radiative flow between two stretchable rotating disks. Effects of Joule heating and thermal radiation are accounted. Homogenous and heterogeneous reactions are also implemented. The thermophysical characteristics of nanofluids are scrutinized using silver and copper nanoparticles. Statistical declaration and probable error for coefficient of skin friction and heat transfer rate are calculated. System of nonlinear ordinary differential equations is obtained by using appropriate variables. Convergent solutions of the involved problems are obtained and discussed. Skin friction coefficient and Nusselt number are calculated and discussed. Radial and axial velocities have opposite impact for stretching parameters of lower and upper disks. Concentration decays for both Schmidt number and homogeneous reaction variable. Coefficient of skin friction is less for larger rotational parameter at both disks. Opposite behavior of heat transfer rate is observed at lower and upper disks for increasing Eckert number. For limiting cases comparisons with previously available results [23,52,53] in the literature are made and an excellent agreement is noticed. © 2017 Hydrogen Energy Publications LLC.
